attributesChanged.text: Road closures are in the scope of METR
METR needs to be resilient as possible in times of major disasters

For the foreseeable future, METR should be viewed as a supplement to existing traffic control  devices rather than a replacement of those features. However, it is likely that this will evolve over time and systems need to convey the level of reliability that vehicles should have on METR data. In the near-term, it is expected to assist ADS/ADAS vehicles to discover information in advance and to more clearly disambiguate details (e.g. some text on sign might be hard to read or sign might be partially obstructed), but our assumption is that vehicles must provide for sufficiently safe operations even if conditions are not completely entered within METR when the jurisdiction claims to support METR (e.g., it should be able to detect a lane closure and respond appropriately; it should be able to detect that it is going well above the prevailing speed and slow down as needed). This might imply some operational changes in the way that emergency responders and other field crew perform their jobs

In some cases, authorities might disable communication systems to prevent misuse (e.g., during 7/7 in London, the authorities diabled the cellular system to prevent potential coordination among terrorists). This should receive a small mention in the ConOps somewhere. Conversely, it was mentioned that updates can become critical in some cases, such as an earthquake moving an entire roadway.

Transport user systems need to know what capabilities are supported for locations which they plan to travel. These capabilities need to reflect: the types of rules supported, the jurisdictions and geofences where the information is supported, the classification of roads and vehicles for which the information is supported, and whether the information includes both static and dynamic rules.
Transport user systems need to know how legally binding the METR information is.

Map information within METR has to be able to accommodate the movement of the Earth's crust. In other words, user systems need to be able to associate map information to the physical world, even when the physical world has shifted.
The information provided by METR is safety critical and must be secure and trustworthy since its intended use is for controlling vehicle operations.

METR data needs to be available to users other than the traditional transport user. For example, it needs to be available to lawyers, insurance companies, enforcement organizations, and traveller's preparing for a long journey.

UNECE WP 1 and WP 29 might recommend the adoption of regulations that require the support of METR either for jurisdictions to support METR distribution systems or for vehicle to support METR user systems.

Some jurisdictions might adopt regulations that require the support of METR either for sub-jurisdictions to support METR distribution systems or for vehicles to support METR user systems. We should mention that UNECE WP 1 and WP 29 might recommend the adoption of such recommendations.

The Management of Electronic Transport Regulations document series is intended to provide users with trustworthy, timely, authoritative, machine-interpretable, transport-related rules as established by jurisdictional entities. The general flow of METR information is described as follows:

    METR starts with rule-makers defining rules that are relevant to transport users

    Rules are securely translated into an electronic format and electronically signed

    Rules are collected from various translators for a specific scope

    Rules are disseminated to transport users as necessary

    Transport-related users become aware of the rules, verify their authenticity, and respond appropriately

This document has been developed by ISO/TC 204 in coordination with many experts from countries around the world. It is designed to be sufficiently generic to be used as an international standard applicable to any country that wishes to adopt its processes.

System developers and system operators within countries that adopt the METR model should become familiar with this document and use it as their guide in operations.

Resources used in the development of this document include those listed in Section 2 and the Bibliography. This document is the first in the ISO 24315 series; other documents in this series are expected to include requirements and design specifications for components of the METR system.

The Management of Electronic Traffic Regulations (METR) document series is intended to provide users access to geo-specific, trustworthy, timely, authoritative, machine-interpretable, traffic and transport related rules enacted by jurisdictional entities. The general flow of METR information is described as follows:

   METR starts with rule-makers defining rules that are relevant to transport users;

   rules are translated into a secure, standardized electronic format and electronically signed;

   the secure, standardized electronic rules are collected from various translators for a specific scope;

   geo-specific rules are disseminated to transport users; and

   transport-related users become aware of the METR data, verify their authenticity, and respond appropriately

METR is designed to assist developers and manufacturers of driving automation systems (i.e., automation Levels 1-5) and driver information systems (including at automation Level 0) to electronically obtain traffic rules to better enable: 

    interacting safely with other road users; 

    following instructions from law enforcement authorities, and those authorized to direct traffic; 

    maintaining smooth and safe flow of traffic;

following instructions from law enforcement authorities, and those authorized to direct traffic;

The general flow of METR information is described as follows:
METR starts with rule-makers defining rules that are relevant to transport users;
METR starts with responsible legal authorities defining and enacting rules that are relevant to transport users;
rules are translated into a secure, standardized electronic format and electronically signed;
legal rules are translated into METR rules, which is a secure, standardized electronic format that includes a digital signature of the translation agent;
each legal rule is translated into a METR rule, which is a secure, standardized electronic representation that includes a digital signature of the approving authority;
the secure, standardized electronic rules are collected from various translators for a specific scope;
METR rules are collected from various translators for a specific scope;
METR rules are collected for a geographic area and specific scope;
geo-specific rules are disseminated to transport users; and
geo-specific rules are disseminated to transport users;
rules are disseminated to transport users based on their needs;
rules are disseminated to METR users based on their needs;
transport-related users become aware of the METR data, verify their authenticity, and respond appropriately; and
transport-related users become aware of the METR rules, verify their authenticity, and respond appropriately; and
as needed, transport-related users can submit discrepancy reports to a discrepancy handler for investigation and correction.

Figure 0-1 provides an overview of the data and devices included within the scope of METR. METR includes both pre-announced rules, which are typically static and are conveyed by various wide-area communication systems, and ad-hoc rules, which are typically conveyed by roadside communication units and perhaps also by wide-area communication systems. Supplemental data provides context to the rules and can be transmitted by wide-area communication systems, roadside communication units, other vehicles, or on-board devices. The rules cover virtually any rule related to surface transport operations; the graphic depicts rules for freight vehicles, kerbside usage, ride sharing, micromobility operations, vulnerable road users (VRUs), public transport usage, automated driving systems, driving, lane usage, pathway robots, and road works. This information and more needs to be conveyed to all transport user systems (i.e., the systems used by transport users); sample user systems shown in Figure 0-1 include nomadic devices, pathway robots, vehicles equipped with driving automation systems.

Figure 0-1 provides an overview of the data and devices included within the scope of the METR environment. Traffic rules and their dissemination have three orthogonal characteristics that are often confused with one another.

    Rules can be permanent or temporary based on whether there is an expectation that the rule will terminate.

    Rules can be distributed through a wide-area distribution mechanism or a local distribution mechanism.

    Rules can be pulled by users well in advance of their need (a.k.a., "pre-announced rule distribution") or pushed to users as special conditions necessitate (a.k.a., "ad-hoc rule distribution").

It is expected that the characteristics of users and the limitations on data capacities for local distribution mechanisms mean that virtually all permanent rules will be distributed from a wide-area, pre-announced distribution source. By comparison, the dynamic nature of many temporary rules will require a local, ad-hoc distribution source. However, it is important to note that those two combinations are only typical use cases and that METR supports every possible combination of these three characteristics.

In addition, supplemental data may provide context to the rules and can be transmitted by wide-area communication systems, roadside units, other vehicles, or on-board devices.

The rules cover virtually any rule related to surface transport operations; the graphic depicts rules for freight vehicles, kerbside usage, ride sharing, micromobility operations, vulnerable road users (VRUs), public transport usage, Automated Driving Systems (ADS, i.e., automation levels 3-5), driving driving, lane usage, pathway robots, and road works. This information needs to be conveyed to all transport user systems (i.e., the systems used by transport users); sample user systems shown in Figure 0-1 include nomadic devices, pathway robots, vehicles equipped with driving automation systems.

The rules cover virtually any rule related to surface transport operations; the graphic depicts rules for freight vehicles, kerbside usage, ride sharing, micromobility operations, vulnerable road users (VRUs), public transport usage, driving (i.e., human-in-the-loop, including driver support systems, which represent Levels 1 and 2 of automation), Automated Driving Systems (ADS, i.e., automation Levels 3-5), lane usage, automated mobile robots (AMRs), and road works. This information needs to be available and conveyed to all actors in the systems used by transport users; the example user systems shown in Figure 0-1 include: nomadic devices, AMRs, vehicles equipped with driving automation systems (i.e., Levels 1-5 of automation).

It is expected that the characteristics of users and the limitations on data capacities for local distribution mechanisms mean that virtually all permanent rules will be pre-announced and distributed from a wide-area distribution source, likely using a pull mechanism. In addition, supplemental data may provide context to the rules and can be transmitted by wide-area communication systems, roadside units, other vehicles, or on-board devices.

Global Standards: ISO standards are developed to address global stakeholder needs. Other international organizations (e.g., UNECE) also play a role in standards development and implementation policies. The first set of ISO standards and specifications for ISO 24315 Management of Electronic Traffic Regulations (METR) are under development and are intended to provide a framework based on the ISO-specified systems engineering methodology and will consist an overall concept of operations, terminology, a reference architecture, and system requirements focused on interoperability. Further information on systems engineering can be found in [2]. METR specifications and standards will ensure interoperability but will need to be interpreted and adapted for regional use.

Other international organizations (e.g., UNECE) also play a role in standards development and implementation policies. The first set of ISO standards and specifications for the ISO 24315 series Management of Electronic Traffic Regulations (METR) are under development and are intended to provide a framework based on the ISO-specified systems engineering methodology and will consist an overall concept of operations, terminology, a reference architecture, and system requirements focused on interoperability. Further information on systems engineering can be found in [2]. METR specifications and standards will ensure interoperability but will need to be interpreted and adapted for regional use.

Global Standards: ISO standards are developed to address global stakeholder needs. Other international organizations (e.g., UNECE) also play a role in standards development and implementation policies. The first set of ISO documents of the ISO 24315 series provide a framework based on the ISO-specified systems engineering methodology, as defined by ISO/IEC  29148 [2], and consist of a vocabulary, a concept of operations, a reference architecture, and requirements for the METR system of systems (SoS). Subsequent documents in the ISO 24315 series will define requirements for each component system within the METR SoS and other requirements common to all component systems. However, in order to ensure interoperability, these documents will need to be interpreted and adapted for regional use.

Global Standards: ISO standards are developed to address global stakeholder needs. Other international organizations (e.g., UNECE) also play a role in standards development and implementation policies. The first set of ISO documents of the ISO 24315 series provide a framework based on the ISO-specified systems engineering methodology, as defined by ISO/IEC  29148 [2], and consist of a vocabulary, a concept of operations, a reference architecture, and requirements for the METR system of systems (SoS). Subsequent documents in the ISO 24315 series will define requirements for each component system within the METR SoS and other requirements common to all component systems. The ISO 24315 series will promote semantic interoperability, but will need to be interpreted and adapted for regional use to provide complete interoperability.

Regional Interoperability:  Each region (e.g., EU, Japan, Korea) customizes international specifications and standards, based on their specific needs and environment, as necessary to provide cross-border interoperability. With respect to the METR, its reference physical architecture should be refined to provide regional implementation guidance. For example, in Europe, METR may eventually become part of the National Access point (NAP).  Furthermore, legacy data formats including TN-ITS, DATEX-II, TPEG2, TransModel, TMDD, and WZDx may be used.  Any, or all, of these formats may be updated to conform to METR trustworthiness requirements.

Regional Interoperability:  Each region (e.g., EU, Japan, Korea) customizes international specifications and standards, based on their specific needs and environment, as necessary to provide cross-border interoperability within the region. With respect to METR, the reference physical architecture should be refined to provide regional implementation guidance. For example, in Europe, METR may eventually become part of the National Access point (NAP).  Furthermore, legacy data formats including TN-ITS, DATEX-II, TPEG2, TransModel, TMDD, and WZDx may be used.  Any, or all, of these formats may be updated to conform to METR trustworthiness requirements.

Regional Interoperability:  Each region (e.g., EU, Japan, Korea) extends and adapts the ISO 24315 series based on their specific needs and environment, as necessary to provide cross-border interoperability within their region. The METR reference architecture is refined to provide regional implementation guidance. For example, in Europe, METR can eventually become part of the National Access point (NAP). Furthermore, legacy data formats including TN-ITS, DATEX-II, TPEG2, TransModel, TMDD, and WZDx can be refined to support METR requirements or used as-is to deliver METR information to the extent that the data can be supported (i.e., non-METR distribution). The preferred solution is to update these formats to conform to the full set of METR trustworthiness requirements.

The purpose of this document is to:

This document will assist driving automation systems in meeting the recommendations of the UNECE WP.1 for complying with traffic rules, including those referring to: 

     Interacting safely with other road users; 

     Following instructions from law enforcement authorities, and those authorized to direct traffic; 

     Maintaining smooth and safe flow of traffic. [6]

This document will assist the following stakeholders in understanding and validating the proposed system:

     Transport users (e.g., automobile drivers, vulnerable road users)

     Transport infrastructure operators (e.g., traffic engineers, toll road operators, parking facility operators)

     Maintenance and construction personnel (e.g., road crews, maintenance managers)

     Transport service operators (e.g., public transport agencies, delivery companies, ridesourcing companies)

     Transport entity owners (e.g., municipalities, campus owners, fleet managers)

     Enforcement personnel (e.g., law enforcement, lawyers, insurance companies)

     Manufacturers and developers (e.g., motor vehicle manufacturers, pathway robot manufacturers, driving automation system developers)

     Technology specialists (e.g., ADS-equipped vehicle experts, location perception experts, video image processing experts)

     Information support entities (e.g., map providers, navigation providers, traveller information providers)

     Advocates (e.g., safety advocates, environmental advocates, disability rights advocates)

In addition, this document will assist in verifying that the requirements, which will be documented in subsequent parts of this standard series, meet the user needs by using a formal traceability table.

The purpose of this document is to define the operational concept (ConOps) for METR. A ConOps is a user-oriented document that describes system characteristics for a proposed system from the users' viewpoint. It includes a description of the stakeholders along with their roles and responsibilities. It describes what the system will do (not how it will do it) and why (rationale). The ConOps is used to communicate overall quantitative and qualitative system characteristics to the acquirer, user, supplier, and other organizational elements (ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2018). The ConOps is a critical tool in building consensus among stakeholders.

The purpose of this document is to define the operational concept (ConOps) for METR. A ConOps is a user-oriented document that describes system characteristics for a proposed system from the users' viewpoint. It includes a description of the stakeholders along with their roles and responsibilities. It describes what the system will do (not how it will do it) and why (rationale). The ConOps is used to communicate overall quantitative and qualitative system characteristics to the acquirer, user, supplier, and other organizational elements (ISO/IEC/IEEE 29148:2018). The ConOps is a critical tool in building consensus among stakeholders.

The purpose of this document is to define formal requirements for the METR translation system, which is responsible for translating legal rules into signed electronic rules and to make these rules available to distribution systems.

The purpose of this document is to define the formal requirements for the METR user system, which is responsible for obtaining relevant rules from distribution systems and providing to an interpreter function that combines the rules with supplemental data in a manner that fufils the needs of the ultimate user.

The purpose of this document is to define the formal requirements for the METR user system, which is responsible for obtaining relevant rules from distribution systems and providing to an interpreter function that combines the rules with supplemental data in a manner that fufils the needs of the ultimate user. The METR user system is also responsible for managing the reporting of any discrepancies discovered by the interpreter.

This document has been developed by ISO/TC 204 in coordination with many experts from countries around the world. It is designed to be sufficiently generic to be used as an international standard applicable to any national or regional authority that wishes to adopt its processes.

System developers and system operators within authorities that adopt the METR model are advised to become familiar with this document and use it as their guide in operations.

Resources used in the development of this document include those listed in Clause 2 and the Bibliography.
